newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corporate earnings show unexpected strength.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corporate earnings show unexpected strength.

text.p: U.S. corporate earnings for the first quarter of 1997 have been better than expected with a peppy economy helping companies out on the bottom line.

"You've seen a lot of companies senstive to the economy doing better than expected on the bottom line," said Bill Miller, chief investment officer at IDS Equity Advisors. He said the economy boosts the "top line" where the revenue shows up and with cost controls in place more of that revenue winds up as profit.

With first-quarter earnings already out from banks, brokers, media companies, consumer products companies, the automakers and quite a few technology companies, surprises of a positive nature dominated over the disappointments.

"The market is continuing to reward those with good performance," siad Karl Rauch, managing director of Rubicon Holdings Inc, a Bala Cynwyd, Pa.-based asset manager. "Those companies that aren't (delivering good earnings) you see getting hit." He noted that apparel-maker Russell Corp fell 8-1/2 to 27-1/4 Friday after reporting earnings of $0.30 per share, versus the consensus expectation of $0.34.

Rauch also noted that Microsoft Corp soared Friday after the software company late the previous day reported earnings of $0.79 per share for its fiscal third quarter, compared to the consensus forecast of $0.64.

Hugh Johnson, market strategist at First Albany Co, noted that with not quite half the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 reporting earnings, 125 beat expectations, 54 were worse than expected. and about 40 were on-target. Johnson said he has not been surprised by the general trend but only with the specifics of some of the reports. "Microsoft, Intel Corp and the autos were pretty darn good," he said.
The banks have generally reported earnings on target, with fee income boosting results and trading helping out at some of the bigger companies.
One analyst thought that Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp had to stretch things to produce earnings that were on-target or slightly better than forecast.
"I don't think people can be happy with the quality of the earning," said Lawrence Cohn of PaineWebber Group Inc, arguing that there was too much reliance on non-recurring gains.

"If you're in the financial transaction business you can't knock out a transaction because it happened," countered Thomas Jones, principal financial officer at Citicorp, in an interview. Jones said there were only two things in Citicorp's massive earnings report that he considered "one-timers." One, he said, was a $50 million after-tax recovery on a settlement with Peru. At the same time the company booked a $72 million pre-tax non-cash expense for performance-based options. He also noted that it was the last of those options.
Citicorp earned $2.01 per share diluted compared to the Institutional Brokers Estimate Systems estimate of $1.99.
For some companies, sharply higher earnings are leading analysts to revise their full year estimates higher.
Johnson believes profits generally will continue to rise throughout the year but at a slower pace. "I'm not in the camp that says profits will turn down," he said.
"I think comparisons do get harder as we go through the year," said Miller. But he said very early in the second quarter the good economic tone of the first quarter seems to be spilling over.
Rauch, who hasn't bought bonds for two years, thinks yields are now at a point where it is time to get back in.
